description: From Anglo-Norman peremptorie, parentorie et al. (Modern French péremptoire), and its source, Latin peremptōrius (“deadly; decisive”), from perimō (“destroy”), from per- (“thorough”) + emō (“I take, I acquire”).

adjectives.description: peremptory (comparative more peremptory, superlative most peremptory)

entries.meaning: (law) Precluding debate or expostulation; not admitting of question or appeal
examples: there is no reason but if any of the outlawries be indeed without error, but it should be a peremptory plea to the person in a writ of error, as well as in any other action.

entries.meaning: Positive in opinion or judgment; absolutely certain, overconfident, unwilling to hear any debate or argument (especially in a pejorative sense); dogmatic.
examples: He marched under a placard reading "End Bossiness Now" but decided it was a little too peremptory, not quite British, so changed the slogan on subsequent badges, to "End Bossiness Soon."

entries.meaning: Accepting no refusal or disagreement; imperious, dictatorial.
examples: […]  less surprising than that he had been depressed by a book. Something was making him nibble at the edge of stale ideas as if his sturdy physical egotism no longer nourished his peremptory heart.

entries.meaning: (law) A challenge to the admission of a juror, without the challenger needing to show good cause.
examples: Each side was allowed 20 peremptories, and the prosecution used 18 of its allotment.
